content:
If you've forgotten your email password, the first step is to utilize your email provider's password recovery options. Typically, this involves going to gmail.com, yahoo.com, OR whatever your provider is, then clicking "Forgot Password" on the login page. After that, you are just following the prompts to verify your identity.

Once that is done, you can re-enter it into thunderbird. You Can go to Settings -> Privacy and Security, Saved Passwords to remove the old one and add the new one.
creator: Thundamike

content: You saw the customer name because you blind-copied yourself on the message to that person, Those on the BCC list will see the message as it was sent to the original recipient. You could send BCC to recipients and in the TO, just leave it blank. Thunderbird will display 'unknown recipients'. You can confirm this by sending a BCC messages to yourself and omit the TO field.
creator: davidsk

content:
re : I can not find a Help button for general questions

'Help' can be found in two places and nothing has changed in a long time. You can access it via the Menu app icon OR via the 'Menu Bar' toolbar.

In Thunderbird Via 'Menu app icon':

  • Click on the 'Menu app icon' (it has 3 horizontal lines and located on the Unified Toolbar - right side) to see drop down list
  • Select 'Help' and click on 'Get Help'

In Thunderbird via 'Menu Bar' toolbar If you cannot see the 'Menu Bar' toolbar you may need to enable it.

To enable the 'Menu Bar' toolbar

  • Click on the 'Menu app icon' (it has 3 horizontal lines and located on the Unified Toolbar - right side) to see drop down list
  • Click on 'View' > click on 'Toolbars' > click on 'Menu Bar'

The Menu Bar toolbar will appear and 'Help' is the last menu item from left to right.

  • Click on 'Help' then click on 'Get Help'

It will open a new tab in browser on this forum. You can choose to browse through Help Articles or specific topics or Ask a question.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
To show the "new message" button:

Click view > folders > folder pane header. if menu bar not visible, click alt key first.
creator: mozilla98

content:
re : I now I can not find a way to send another email to her

Above the Folder Pane where you see the list of mail accounts and their folders is the 'Folder Pane Header' The Folder Pane Header' contains the following from left to right: A cloud icon which means 'Get Messages' In the middle is a large '+New Message' button which means click on me and it will open a new Write message so you can create an email.

If you cannot see that 'Folder Pane Heade' toolbar then maybe you closed it. To display it again:

  • Click on the 'Menu app icon' (it has 3 horizontal lines and located on the Unified Toolbar - right side) to see drop down list
  • click on 'View' > click on 'Folders' > click on 'Folder Pane Header'

Click on '+New Message' button A new Write message window opens. In 'To' field enter email address OR use the 'Contacts Sidebar' where you can select an address book, ten select name of person and clickon 'Add to TO' button.

Type a suitable brief topic in the Subject line Now you can compose your email. To add an image:

  • click on 'Insert' to see drop down options
  • Click on 'Image'
  • click on 'Choose File'
  • Locate the image and select the image file and click on openenter alternative text and click on OK
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: mozilla98

content:
Sorry if you already know some of the following information. I cannot tell from your message how much experience you have with Thunderbird.

The Thunderbird application and data are separate. Thunderbird on your Mac can access data on an external drive, so there is no need to install Thunderbird on an external drive. Just install it in Applications on your Mac.

Data is stored in profiles. You can create a profile on your external drive, import the mbox files by copying or moving them into your profile in the file system (not in Thunderbird, but you could do that too), and tell the Thunderbird app to use that profile.

how do I make sure TB knows that the data from the mbox(es) I import should "live" on the external drive as well?

I'm not sure that I understand. Are you expecting to end up with two instances of the data? After you import into Apple Mail, you will want only one instance of the data on the external drive. It will be in your Thunderbird profile and that will be the only place where Thunderbird accesses it.

Thunderbird never needs to know about any external e-mail accounts, including gmail.

Is this the approach that you want to take? You may need more information for each step of this process. Please ask again if you do, OK?
creator: mozilla98
